newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany releases Canadian anti-whaling activist.
newsitem.headline: Germany releases Canadian anti-whaling activist.

text.p: Authorities in the German city of Bremen released Canadian anti-whaling activist Paul Watson from detention on Tuesday even though Norway wants him arrested for trying to sink a whaling ship in 1992.
Watson was detained in the port of Bremerhaven on Monday on an international arrest warrant.

But the high court in the city of Bremen ruled that the 120-day sentence he had received in Norway in 1994 was too short to provide the basis of an extradition under German law, a spokesman for the Bremen prosecutors' office said.
Watson, 46, was convicted of opening the flood valves of the whaling ship in port, causing around $60,000 of damage, but failed to turn up for his sentence.

Watson is the head of a militant anti-whaling group called Sea Shepherd. He was one of the founders of the environmental group Greenpeace but left 20 years ago because it was not aggressive enough in its anti-whaling campaigns, Greenpeace's German headquarters in Hamburg said.
